body: @RobotCaleb Does this help colorblind gamers?
Probably only as much as ordinary people - color blindness affects only hues from what I know.
Is it on purpose that the "shadow" is actually drawn above the text?

It's not drawn above the text, but the shadow is indeed on the top-left. I found it made things more readable compared to the shadow being on the bottom-right. You can compare yourself by replacing the `-1` on [this line](https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/11693/files#diff-af8247f6d0d31e2b5135557ba1aac4a8R99) with `1`. I'm fine with changing that if that's just due to my quirky eyes.
Could someone post a screenshot of these new shadows?

I agree with pchote. Please provide me with some media to review. I'm not in a state to build and test myself. (This sort of PR should probably always include reference.)

Thanks for providing the screenshots.

In the Bleed Pool Party shot, Team 2's Russian Naval AI label is mostly invisible to me. Adding the shadow definitely helps me. (Not all color vision deficiencies are equal)

As for the shadows, bottom right is much better than top left. (that is, light coming from top left to cast shadow to bottom right) Team 4 Rush AI in bottom right is a bit hard to read but much easier to read than no shadow at all. (Without a shadow it is actually not visible to me. I can tell something is there, but am unable to read it.)

Having written similar code many times I've come to the conclusion that simply redrawing the text offset by 1.4 pixels doesn't always end up being the right answer. For the stuff I'm currently doing, I actually draw a blob and put the text on it. I do use it to solve a slightly different problem. This likely won't fit the UI needs of OpenRA, though.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/113401/17116628/f032efb0-5275-11e6-8b5b-78c642f8339a.png)

I do hope this all makes sense. I wrote this rather hastily.

We have some mismatches in the chat highlighting:
- In the lobby player names use the default shadow color only
- In the overlay (no text box) ingame chat display player names use the smart alternate color, but displayed as a contrast instead of a shadow
- In the textbox chat display player names don't use any contrast or shadow.
This is a really nice polish improvement overall.  :+1: after fixing the above nits.

Updated. Changes:
- Fixed the missing shadows on the shroud dropdowns.
- Fixed the TD shadow colors.
- Added shadows to all the columns in the observer stats window.
- Added shadow to the line graph in the observer stats window.
- Added shadow to more chat messages. The chat overlay (ie, the one without visible UI) continues to use the contrast option with automatic color selection, while everything that is drawn on top of UI elements uses shadow with the default colors from metrics.yaml.

I think that's about it. I might still have missed something, so someone give this another once-over, please.

Looks a bit blurred to me in cases where it isn't really necessary to add contrast:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/756669/17457011/72d4533c-5bea-11e6-9b5b-4c6deb697922.png)
We could avoid that with per-case checks to only add the shadow if the main color is "too close" to the background (hello, colour validator!)... but that is kind of ugly.
For the record, I agree that bottom-right shadow looks much better (that's what WW used for TS' font, too).

> Looks a bit blurred to me in cases where it isn't really necessary to add contrast:

In that situation it looks much nicer to use `WidgetUtils.GetContrastColor` which returns black:

![screen shot 2016-08-26 at 18 19 52](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/167819/18014255/f92609a6-6bb9-11e6-9ba1-d1b22fbc43c0.png)

Unfortunately this then looks quite nasty when you have a dark coloured name:

![screen shot 2016-08-26 at 18 20 21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/167819/18014269/06aa514a-6bba-11e6-905e-13f0ea6427c2.png)

It's more work and boilerplate, but my best suggestion right now to make this look polished in more situations is to change `WidgetUtils.GetContrastColor` to take the light/dark colours as arguments, and then let the mods define those on a per-widget basis.  For most of the UI I think we can keep #7F7F7F for the shadow of dark colours, and use #000000 as the shadow for light colours.
OK, updated. Not sure if I'm happy with this.
